author: theleaper27

title: Routerized Cupcake CNC  for 6.7 mm plywood and some mods

description.text:
Update 20110725: After a long interruption, finished, tested, commissioned and reportedly reproducing a Prusa in the wild. ;-) Runs a 2 month old version of Tonokip firmware and Printrun on the host. Extruder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10202

Just finished cutting pandelume's great Routerized Cupcake CNC: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1864
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1881
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1882 It was a fairly involved process, since the closest material I could find is 6.7 mm thick beech plywood: so I adapted the thickness of the slots and similar. I also introduced some small mods, documented in the pictures. By order of perceived usefulness:
  • Brass bushings scavenged from discarded printers (my preferences go to Epson, the older, the better). X and Y holes for bars adapted consequently. Y axis is 8 mm brass rod (brass on brass = smooth as silk, we'll see how long it lasts), X axis bars are 9.5 mm chromed and polished printer carriage bars. Bushings are press-fit, after good alignment I put a couple of drops of cyanacrylate glue on the perimeter, then a layer of epoxy-metal.
  • Added M3 threaded bar right under the bushings, allows to better adjust alignment of the bushings to the bars, a good adjustment significantly reduces friction.
  • Added rubber feet to the bot (from another discarded printer)
  • Added 10 mm height to the lower compartment since I am having issues with placing my power supply because of the increased thickness of the panels, and reversed the cutouts and drill holes in the power panel. (notice this is only in the plans)
    • Notice that I am using the Z stage adapted for the ACME screws http://abella.net/?page_id=306 As the build goes on, I am quite happy with the results of the cut. IMHO the dxf files could still be improved. Because of tool size correction, I could not use the 1/8 cutter directly - emc2 barfs at the 1.5 mm radius cuts when informed the cutter diameter is 3.1 mm Update 20101020: While mounting the X carriage to the body, I discovered that the clearance to the bottom is insufficient (this is due to the increased thickness of the plywood), so I shaved off 1 mm in the X_left_right and in the X_rib dxfs. I replaced these files in the uploaded set.

Edit the dxf files at your discretion.
I used Qcad http://www.qcad.org/
To convert to gcode I used dxftogcode http://code.google.com/p/dxf2gcode/
set cutter diameter correction paths separatedly. I generated separate files for cut_inside and cut_outside layers, since I was using different diameter cutters: a 2 mm diam. straight cutter in four passes for all the fine detail, and a 1/8 twin flute spiral straight cutter for the contours (3 passes) and drilling the holes. I edited by hand the gcode file for drilling since dxftogcode does not (yer) manage dxf point data. Should you need them, I can upload the gcode files too, but be warned that they are not fully up-to-date with the mods, and they tend to be quite machine-specific.
Other dxf to gcode converters might work as well, there's even an extension for Autocad.
I am using emc2/Axis http://linuxcnc.org/ to control a 6040 CNC router. Cutting speed was 400 mm/mn, spindle speed near maximum.
Precision was usually better than 0.1 mm, and the pieces required only light edge deburring.

I loved Lucas Hardi's Orc Bust, but there were a few problems with the mesh around the teeth. I'm sure his Orc mom told him "be sure to brush and floss after eating Hobbitsies" but obviously he did not. NetFabb online fixed some of the cavities, but one tooth was so bad that it needed to be pulled. Luckily with the help of 3dCoat I was able to clone one of his good teeth and transplant it. I gold leafed the replacement tooth in my print in honor of my new skills in Orc dentistry. I also boolean punched a screw hanger (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243313) into the back because I wanted to hang him on the wall to serve as a warning to all the tiny plastic Orcs in my neighborhood. Keep up the good work Lucas. I look forward to seeing more. Even if the mesh isn't perfect there are plenty of folks up here who would be happy to help fix things. We talked about this thing and a whole lot more about 3d printing on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

comments.text: Ah! Terrific!  I ran into a lot of problems trying to work with the original. Figured I'd work on it later, closer to Halloween, but now I don't have to!
comments.author: kittka

title: Updated: Z-axis Anti-backlash 1/4-16 Acme Threaded Modification

description.text:
Build Anti-Backlash for 1/4-16 Acme Z axis rods
.
Materials Needed :
  • 2x 12" 1/4-16 Acme Rod (McMasterCarr #: 93410A904 per)
  • 4x 1/2" wide nuts (McMasterCarr #: 94815A007 per)
  • 1x spring (McMasterCarr #: 1986K94 package of 6)
  • 4x (3mm or 4-40) x 1.5" long bolts and matching nuts
    .
    The top nut will press fit into the top and the bottom nut will be loose. The bottom nut should also be within the case so no pressure from installation interferes or presses on this nut. The top nut is the driving nut while the bottom nut provides the anti-backlash.
    Also uses either 3mm or 4-40 threaded bolts at 1.5 inches long.

comments.text: What is the spring for?
comments.author: kd7eir

comments.text: The spring pushes the nuts apart which keeps a constant thread engagement on the rod reducing backlash.
comments.author: kd7eir

comments.text: So far this is the best mod I have done to my printer.  bed leveling is more accurate ( I don't have auto bed leveling yet) my layers are more consistent.   The stock threaded rods I got had a slight bend in them, I tried to straighten them with no luck.   Thanks for sharing a great mod!

comments.text: Since you are using 2 12" z rods what is the new z height limit?  Would it be worth cutting down a 36" rod to keep the factory z rod length?   I have 2 12" rods but the factory ones are 16" long.  the foil tape on the lower nut I assume is to take out more of the play?
comments.author: brochapman

comments.text: It's some where around 7". At this point, I haven't needed to print anything that tall yet. If you cut down the 36" rods you can gain 1.5 to 2".

I've read that the ACME threaded rods are made for linear movement, have smoother travel and tighter tolerance than standard threaded rods. So I gave it try. The rods from mc master were still bent alittle but not nearly as much as the provided M5 rods with the i3v.

These spinner covers is designed to fill the gap between the RVJET fuse and the spinner that comes in the RVJET power package. The cover has cooling outlet ducts to let cooling air out from the ESC and motor compartment. They are meant to be glued directly on the rear of the fuse. If needed there are some slots into which 3x1mm CF-strips can be used for reinforcements. An up-arrow shows how the cover should be aligned.   
Disclaimer: The cover is designed to be slightly smaller then the foam since foam can shrink depending on temperature and mechanical stress. In the renders you can see a slight edge but it should look better in real life. I have also not tried these from Shapeways myself but have printed using a FDM-printer. Please contact me if there is any questions and also please report back how well these fit and if any changes needs to be done to the design.
OBSERVE: This was designed to fit the first RV power pack 3550 motor which was quite long. Because of this it might be too long for later versions of the power pack.

comments.text: Looks really nice, but seems to be a little too long. I have the renewed power pack, and can only barely get the spinner attached to the motor shaft when this spinner cover is in place. I am going to try shaving off a little bit to see if i can slide the spinner more securely attached.

comments.text:
Hi. The model is solid on purpose, because depending on shell thickness you can make the part as strong as yo need. For example in the photo it has only one contour of filament (0.5mm thick) and it went out wery light, but also very fragile. After I made some with shell thicknes of 1mm and 1.5mm. Those parts were much stronger. So you can adjust it easily. Same applies to the bottom thickness. I sugest to leave it at 2 or 3mm.
How to make it hollow during the printing is within print settings. For example, in RepetierHost (using CuraEngine Slicer) there is an option in STRUCTURES: SOLID-TOP-INFILL and SOLID-BOTTOM-INFIL. I just unselect the SOLID-TOP-INFILL and leave 0% infill and it´s ready to go.
If you have no such option in your software to adjust it, I can upload a different version with the shell thickness of your need.

title: Amsterdamman's Ormerod hot bed indicator light cover

description.text: This is a small blocker for the LED light on the Ormerod hot bed. After an injury left me sensitive to optic nerve migraines I block LED light sources such as on the hot bed indicator.

To install simply remove the second nut under the hot bed middle bolt. The flange is slotted so does not need to be fitted around the screw and takes the place of the removed nut. Replace the lowest nut to secure the bed.
I added the words HOT and ON which are seen when the unit is heating. The words are slightly too large for the light source, but the main purpose is to block off the light while still allowing enough light to be easily seen to pass. There is also some play as the piece is made slightly loose fitting but it does the intended function well enough.

description.text: A prusajr Mendel printable on a Makerbot or Huxley or any other small printer. Requires 85x98mm of active area. Bushings are included in a separate file and must be printed in PLA. description.text:
This is a millinery hat block, the foundation for all hand made hats. After it is printed out, a velour hat body would be steamed and stretched over it, and left to dry. Once removed, it will keep the shape of the block.
Made some recent edits to separate the brim and crown blocks onto a single printable surface and added a top piece which reinforces the depression on top of the hat.

This is my first attempt at OpenSCAD, and I haven't been able to get a MakerBot yet. So I am unsure as to the results of actually blocking a hat on this block. I am 100% open to your critiques and suggestions to improve.

comments.text: Hi David, What is that $Fn parameter requested by Customizer?
comments.author: flaneur

comments.text: Basically controls the resolution of the surface. The higher the number, the smoother the curves. From the OpenSCAD manual:

Thanks David, The crown and brim blocks make sense to me, but please excuse my ignorance, what is the third block, and how is it used? BTW, I'll be using this to re-block my Panama, since I got caught in the rain yesterday.
comments.author: dfisher1342

comments.text: No problem! The third piece flips upside down and is a perfect match with the top of the crown. It will push down and make a nice indentation, otherwise when stretching fabric, it would just pull straight across the top. The extended pieces on either side are so you can tie it down tight with a rope without leaving rope lines on the sides of the crown.
That makes perfect sense, and that addresses one of the problems that I have had with the glorified cardboard block that came with the hat.
comments.author: dfisher1342

title: Star Wars X-Wing Miniatures 40mm laser base

description.text:
ANOTHER NEW VERSION!
Now using 1/16 acrylic rods to generate the line laser. Slightly larger and switched to a CR2032 battery and holder for improved laser output. NEW VERSION! Substantial improvements in fit/size. Still working on a battery power issue (the lasers dim pretty dramatically within a few seconds) This Model is dedicated to Wil Wheaton and his great Table Top show on Youtube. I'm not affiliated with it, but it introduced me to this game and got me back into board games in general. Check it out!
If you play X-wing You've probably gotten in the situation where you can't tell if you're just in the firing arc or you can't fit the whole range ruler into place. For me being a lazy, lazy, lazy mechanical engineer, I thought, it's Star Wars, clearly lasers are necessary. This is a base I designed, the idea is, if you don't know if you're in the firing arc press down the cardboard piece and the lasers light up, both showing a line to the target and lighting up the target too.
So now your X-Wings (or Tie Fighters) can have laser targeting!
Also...very much a work in progress!

Version 6!
1x Printed laser base C6 Some cleanup may be required or change slice settings to a diagonal/etc.
1x CR2032 and battery case http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E0JJYGI/ref=ox_sc_sfl_title_3?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A3G3SQGWUPUX9W
1x tactile switch
2x "Lasers" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00R73MC1S/ref=ox_sc_sfl_title_1?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A321U5OH73UZ8M
2x short lengths of 1/16" acrylic rod Version 4
Parts List!
1x Printed Laser Base C4
2x Lasers: Very compact new version! http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HJIA8C6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
1x Tactile switch You can use just about anything. I specifically used a TE Connectivity: 1977223-1 ...because I had some hanging around. But really any tactile switch in that general profile ought to work
http://www.te.com/catalog/bin/TE.Connect?S=23806&M=PPROP&P=63019,83735&BML=10576,13873&LG=1&PG=1&IDS=126652,438274,420827,485809,485810&N=4
1x CR1225 Battery and battery case: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU9GIQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Wiring is fairly simple. Just remember that a laser diode does need to be connected positive to positive on the battery terminal. I can tell you for personal experience that connecting it the wrong way doesn't work! It doesn't burn anything up either though, so it's okay (in fact if you get that battery holder...just flip the battery...)
I glued all the components into place and then proceeded to solder them in. I chose to go with red going to the switch and blue going to the negative battery terminal, but it's pretty open for interpretation. Maybe I'll try to do an instructable on that section at some point.
The last bit is the little lenses that turn a normal laser into a lineish laser. For those I found that taking some plastic tupperware from ikea and slicing a little square out of the top rib works very effectively. Make sure the as molded end is towards the table.
Again, very much a work in progress! Constructive criticism is welcome. :)

description.text:
Is your pumpkin feeling inferior due to lack of a festive stem?  Do you have no way to easily remove the lid on your stemless Jack-o'-lantern?  Stuck in an impromptu game of curling with a stone shortage?  No problem!  Turn your pumpkin into a cyborg super-pumpkin with this printable prosthetic stem.
We bought a pumpkin from a local patch this weekend, but realized later it had no stem.  I sliced out the stem portion of the excellent thing:4473 model, and mounted it to a hollow cylinder with some "threads."  Although the flat plate between the cylinder and the stem is unsupported, if you turn your MakerBot extrusion flow rate down or up the X-Y travel rate you should be fine.  The sagging seems to be acceptable in my tests and isn't visible from the top.

• Find an underloved stemless pumpkin.
  • Download the STL model.
  • Resize with ReplicatorG to ensure that the inside hole will span the hard stem attachment location.
  • Print in your favorite stem color (yellow, green, or GLOW IN THE DARK).
    (You may want to give Jack an anesthetic now.)
    5a. If you are Superman, grip the stem firmly and crank the stem into the top of your pumpkin.
    5b. For the rest of us, cut a slightly undersized hole in the top of your pumpkin and twist the stem into it. A quarter turn should do it.
  • Enjoy your new and improved pumpkin.

This is a tool that is designed to squeeze liquid filled packets in an orderly fashion. Place the packet edge in the squeezer (for example, a mac-n-cheese packet) and give it a slight turn, cut off the corner opposite the key. Then turn the key to squeeze all the contents out. The packet will turn slightly and bring the cut corner even with the two rollers as you turn it. Yes, you can just use your fingers but this is more fun and does a better job of squeezing. You need the following parts.
1) Key, 2) Small Ends, 2) Large Ends, 1) Handle, 2) Rollers and 4) #0-80 x 1/2" Long Socket Head Cap Screws or similar to bolt it together.

Build the following parts on your 3D printer.
1) Key, 2) Small Ends, 2) Large Ends, 2) Rollers, 1) Frame.
Bolt together using the 4) #0-80 x 1/2" Long screws. Place packet even with and between rollers near the small end of the tool. Crank the key to draw the packet between the rollers. The packet will turn and force the contents of the packet out of the snipped corner. As you crank it, the packet will move towards the large end.

It doesn´t have any practical use, though...

Note: I updated the scad file to make it a bit easier to maintain. The code is cleaner since I learned the module command. :-) This OpenSCAD file (requires OpenSCAD 2014.03 or newer) can be used to generate a model of box with a sliding lid. You can easily edit constants in the OpenSCAD file to adjust the box's dimensions, wall thickness, and even add a small "button" on the lid to make it easier to open. Adjust the values as necessary, export as STL, and import into your favorite slicer/Repetier Host. Depending on the quality of your printer (or if you print a brim), you may need to trim the lid slightly. No support structure should be needed as the lid angles are all 45º.
Open the "lidded box - polyhedron.scad" file into OpenSCAD 2014.03 or newer. Adjust the dimensions, wall thickness, etc. Export as STL and print.

title: Contour Mount for Dye i4 Paintball Mask

description.text: • Reduced the angle on the camera since it is completely mounted to the mask I don't need to account for the head pushing on it. This should help with comfort.
• Comfort adjustments.
• Final before print.
• Added some ledges for the inner teeth to help with printing issues.

• Created some gaps so the lens can be inserted and bottom lip will catch.
  • Added more mounting points.

    Update v3:

  • Removed the teeth.
  • Removed the lip, and designed it to be zip tied at multiple locations.
  • Added supports for the zip tie panel to the mount.

• Added teeth to the bottom of the lip.
  • Added a wedge to counter the tilt that the head causes.
  • Adjusted the Contour bracket to be on one side so the camera can be in the middle of the mask.
    • Description

Been playing paintball with my Contour+2 and wanted to have a proper mount for my Dye i4 Mask.
There are a few holes in the bottom of the "lip" that will allow you to use small zip-ties to affix it to the mask. I've rounded out the back of the attachment, so it doesn't tilt to much from your head.
Model is face down, so it will print a bit cleaner.

comments.text: Super happy to see this made. Had my Contour side mounted on my Vforce Grill, but when I got my i4 mask it had no where good to mount. Sadly, I think my head is a lot bigger than yours. V8 of your build still rubs against the top/front of my head (sometimes shifting the Contour out of it's "clicked in" position) and I find he uptilt angle a little severe and not helping the fit for me. Any chance you want to make a v9 for us big head guys? Other than that, it's a solid and smart build. Just make sure to think through the position you have the bot print it from, otherwise you're sanding a lot or building a second time.

title: Incarna Role Playing Card Game - Gladiator Weapon Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Standard Playing Cards converted to work with the Incarna Role Playing Game System. This is Weapon Card set i used in the "Beryl Summer Gladiator Games" I ran off the back of the sailboat this summer.
http://www.obsidianportal.com/campaigns/beryl-summer-gladiatorial-games I found it handy to have cards to represent random weapons draw before each Gladiator match. However they can be easily converted to whatever scenario or game system you like. They are loosely based on Minor Arcana Tarot Cards. Incarna Role Playing Game System is
CC-Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0)
http://www.incarna.net/pub/news/free/
Inquiries about Use & Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be made at http://www.facebook.com/pages/Infinite-Incarnations/115258981866107. Incarna Game System (Kelly Berger) / CC BY-NC-SA 3.0

Print the Standard sized 2.5in x 3.5in Playing Cards at 100% on US Letter Card Stock. They are 9up to a sheet [A]ce to 9 and [T]en to [F]ool (or Jester) in each suit. I used [P]age (think Princess or Squire as well as a [F]ool in each suite to fill out the matrix. There are also 3 extra cards of each suit, mostly there since they are more typical gladiator weapons. The cards are easily editable in Inkscape so mash them up however you like.

A model based on the yellow submarine
I have provided it in split for support-less printing, as well as full (needing support) Not a perfect replica, but I am looking to make a small model. Modeled in Sculptris

Scale as desired, (small will hide my lazy modeling)
the split model will need to be glued together
Personally I prefer ABS for these situations, as ABS acetone glue-ups
work really well for me.
I have put both halves on the same build plate to allow scaling at one go. my print was scaled down slightly split model
ABS
.15 slice
10% infill
80mm/sec
a few pinholes at these settings
glued with abs/acetone mix (syrup viscosity)
filled in holes by dabbing on the goop, set for 10 seconds
wipe off with a paper towel (repeat where needed)

DGB: DLa7rf98WqV23zffDqNycmjGjgwpwXQuwb Update (2/7/2015): By popular demand, I've opened the vent holes for those who are overclocking (and possibly using the Pi 2). The cart lid has also been fixed to add more support around the connectors. This is an NES-styled case for the Raspberry Pi B+ and Raspberry Pi 2 Model B. It is inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307832 but is a complete re-design from scratch as it only worked with the Raspberry Pi B. USB/Ethernet are mounted in front and MicroSD card is out the back.
The case is held together with 4x #4-40 1" machine screws.

remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi case with holes for M3 screws

title: A More Secure Raspberry Pi Case

description.text:
On a recent project, I needed a more secure case for a Raspberry Pi. The project called for a Raspberry Pi to be semi-permanently mounted inside of a cabinet at a public venue. The security needs were as follows.
  • Case halves secured together by screws
  • SD card fully enclosed to prevent removal
  • Case needed to have mounting points
  • GPIO pins needed to be easily accessible
    • There were plenty of options out there, but none had all of the elements I needed. So I spent a few hours modifying an existing case I found here on Thingiverse. I have included the Sketchup file incase anyone else wants to tinker with it more.
    I also included printing tabs that help prevent warping. These can be easily removed with an Xacto knife or a pair of needle nose pliers. Many thanks to SKG for his / her original design!

When printing the case halves separate or in a plate configuration, make sure that support material is turned on. If support material is not turned on, the top plate to the SD cover will not print correctly.  
For the bolts I am using the same ones as specified in the instructions for the Raspberry Pi Case with Hex Bolts designed by SKG. Part number 6374 from BoltDepot.com which is Metric socket cap, Stainless steel 18-8, 2.5mm x 0.45mm x 16mm. These bolts can also be picked up at Home Depot, Lowes or just about anyplace that sells an assortment of hardware parts.   
I also included printing tabs that help prevent warping. These can be easily removed with an Xacto knife or a pair of needle nose pliers.

remixed_from.title: Blade pitch gauge attachment for iPhone

description.text: I wanted to make a simple way to measure blade pitch with an iPhone 4 and not require screws

Print heliLevel1.stl and heliLevel2.stl and slide them together. download your favorite level from the App store. the pitch gauge is a little loose on the iPhone 4 but I just shimmed with a piece of paper. Also I used a rubber band to make the slide hold the blade.
All the V2 files are the upgrades and replace the originals, this includes being able to use rubber bands to lock on the blade and the iPhone, this resolves the issue of needing shims, all else works the same. If you want to use the upgrades V2 parts just print the 3 V2a, V2b and V2c as they are full replacements. If you would prefer something simpler then the originals work when shimmed. The other two photos of the gauge not on the heli are of the V2 design. I hope someone finds these useful.

description.text: There are many ways to hold an LMxUU bearing. This is mostly a conceptual presentation of one that I (surprisingly) haven't seen yet. Simply print this part and clip retaining rings into the slots on the LMxUU bearing. No more breaking clamps or bearing slippage. Ever wonder what those slots on the LMxUU bearing were for? Now you know!

The scad file is parametric and can be used for any style LMxUU bearings. Just print it off, pop on the appropriate retaining ring and you're done. A simple, robust and elegant way to hold LMxUU bearings.
The picture shows an LM8UU bearing with a 5/8" retaining clip. I'm pretty sure the actual size should be 15mm retaining clips, but I just bought the closest thing I could find at the hardware store and it worked well.
Update: Make sure you get standard size retaining rings and not "heavy duty". The heavy duty ones are too thick to fit the lm8uu slots

title: Roll Cage Swivel Mount for GoPro

description.text: This is an alternative to GoPro's roll bar mount, which has huge posts sticking out the back and does not have the necessary degrees of freedom to get the camera level on an angled bar, such as the A-pillar.  This addresses both of those issues by using zip ties to secure it and adding a swivel to account for skewed angles.  Sized to fit a 1.75 inch tube, although slightly smaller or larger should still work fine.
I thought I may need something to keep the mount from twisting on the tube or swiveling on it's own, but with a couple of tight zip ties, it is extremely sturdy.

Enjoy!
Pretty straightforward until I can throw up a wiring diagram.

These objects aren't so much meant to be printed as they are meant to be used to aid in the design of objects for use with them. This pack contains:
Wiimote
AA Battery
AAA Battery
US Quarter, Nickel, Penny, and Dime
Altoids Tin (and Altoid)
Standard CD/DVD
Mini CD/DVD
Stack of 4 business cards (scale in z to taste!) I'm going to produce a few of these now that I've got a pair of metric calipers to go around probing my world. There should be an electronics pack on the way with standard servo motors, LEDs, Arduino, etc soon. THAT will be super-useful for designing printable robots! The wiimote is a bit incomplete, but one of the nice things about extrinsic shapes is that since we don't mean to actually print them, we can get away with things like grouping buttons onto the Wiimote rather than using geometric union operations. One of these days I may get around to a nice, super-accurate wiimote and nunchuck model. Unless of course companies start publishing .obj files for their products... (Not holding my breath of course!) Philosophical note: This submission feels kind of ironic. I mean, I'm creating a library of the standardized shapes that have been created by the "standardize and mass-produce" methodology, specifically so people can totally subvert it...

Here are the PacMan Ghosts, and there are four types. Each with the eye in a different place!'
It took me about 1.5 hours to do! But it came out pretty awesome! 8 bit ROCKS!

eye position. Also this the thing number 4500 on Thingiverse!
This was my very first print so I still have to calibrate it a little.

title: Archery Quiver PVC Fitting for 2in PVC Pipe

description.text:
Sometimes, instead of carrying a quiver on your bow or your back you just want to retrieve your arrows from the target and drop them in a standing quiver on the shooting line.
This fitting allows you to attach a 2" PVC pipe to a base to hold arrows on the archery range.
The jscad source is included in case you want to tweak to the shape. Of course you can just grab the STL and print it as is also.

To make a free standing range quiver...
  • Print the thing
  • Cut a length of 2in Schedule 40 PVC Pipe 18-20" long (depending on your arrow length and personal preference)
  • Cut a wooden base. 6in x 6in seems to work well. I use 1in (3/4in nominal) pine
  • Draw an X using the corners of the wooden base
  • Position the fitting on the base so that the lines of the X pass through all 4 screw holes. This will center the fitting on the board
  • Mark the locations of the screw holes
  • Remove the fitting and drill pilot holes for the screws
  • Attach the fitting to the base with suitable screws
  • Coat the inside of the fitting with glue or epoxy
  • Insert the PVC pipe, seating it fully in the fitting and then rotate the pipe half a turn or so to distribute the glue

title: Modular Viki LCD mount with integrated mount for Azteeg x5

description.text: This is a mount I made for the Viki LCD controller so that it can be docked or moved to be used while sitting/standing etc. It is made to attach to 20mm t-slot extrusion. There is also a built in mount for the Azteeg X5 board which hangs on the bottom. This keeps it nicely tucked out of the way and makes for easy wiring. With the included cable, the Viki mount can only be used from a distance of about 15" from the base. I plan on extending this harness and integrating an old telephone cable to act as a spring reel of sorts.

description.text:
This is a computer dock, inspired by Griffin's Elevator Notebook Stand. I printed the eight parts in PLA and cut seven pieces of Delrin stock for the legs. Using Delrin was probably overkill - this will work with other (cheaper) materials. 
When in the dock, the bottom of my 15" Macbook Pro is a little more than 3.5" off my desk.

• Print (2) of each part. I used a stock Ultimaker at roughly 75mm/s and 10% fill. I didn't have to worry about supports.

  • Find 4' of 1/4" x 2" stock of something. Cut (4) legs 8" long, (2) leg 5.4" long, and (1) 5.2" long. The 8" legs are for the top and bottom and the 5.4" legs are for the back supports. The 5.2" leg goes across up front.

  • Find 14 bolts and respective tap, or another fastening method (glue? cable ties?). The holes in the printed parts are appropriately sized (and countersunk) for the hardware I used: 4-40 x 3/4" bolts through drilled and taped holes in the Delrin. I put each printed part in place on the stock to make drilling easy - 3/32" bit is fine if you're using 4-40s. Tap if you need to.

  • Assemble and use!

title: Rigid X rod clamp with endstop

description.text:
The X Y Z endstop kit is great, but the clamp with the Z endstop has a somewhat weak middle, leading to bending of the clamp. I prefer having the screws firmly screwed in, so that they stay in position with minimal deformation of the clamps. Since the original clamp has a small section in the middle, it is rather prone to deformation.
To fix this, I have unioned the clamp with the endstop with the TL version of the X clamp. The rather quick and dirty result is a rigid clamp with an endstop.
Please note that the holes for the PBC nuts are not present in the clamp, make sure your screws do not stick out of the top of the clamp before printing this.

description.text: imitate
Intro

The goal of this project was to make a simple and clean utility blade holder. This utility blade holder is quick printing (20 minutes), lightweight, and strong. When no other option is available, this should work in a pinch. Version 2 blade will fit tightly. The ability to use nuts and bolts is optional. Provided you allow the blade to be a permanent part of the knife, you can use ABS slurry to glue in the pins.
Version 1 is pictured. Please note different handle cutout.
Version 2 holds the blade slightly on bottom to prevent falling out. Featured picture credit to CatoNatta.
Parts List

• Body
  • Pins
    Hardware (optional) (all available from McMaster-Carr):
  • 2 x M3 Nuts (http://www.mcmaster.com/#90685A037)
  • 2 x M3 7mm Screw (http://www.mcmaster.com/#91290a115/)
    Read assembly instructions for more details.

    Use

    Not for use on people. Do not use as weapon. I am not responsible for your recklessness with this thing.

    Change List

    v1: Initial release
    v2: Handle cutout changed. Under-blade holder added.

Print body with butt of knife on platform. 10% fill, 2 shells should be fine. Print filled for a stronger knife body. Finish by attaching pins to body, and gluing with ABS slurry. Alternatively, use M3 nuts and bolts.

comments.text: I love the design, but totally cut my finger open. I may attempt a small revision to your design by adding an extra nut and bolt to the end of the blade nearest the finger guard. This would act as a small safeguard for the tip of the blade pivoting and coming out of the handle.

remixed_from.author: outofstep
remixed_from.title: Interstellar Space Jarhead - New Deep Perpetrator door

description.text: Updated

After a bit I discovered that the doors were rotating in the 'closed' position and falling out a bit.  Trimming made them looser.  I could use a magnet (drill little hole in both sides to help hold them shut in the right spot), but I decided that rotating the hinge snaps might work.  So this has the ends of the hinges rotated 90 degrees.  Old doors are in a .zip in case those worked better for you.  
More Drop Pod Stuff

See my full drop pod (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:446893), which is overly complete! I'll try to post a pix in a bit.
Thanks

Thanks a TON to Kushan77 and outofstep!
This one has some greeblies/detail to try to make it a little more fun.
Print on high (.1mm) to get the most detail. I print on supports (no raft), with the interior side facing the bed, and then leave a bit of the rafts on the model, which kind of makes it look a little like tread.
Please support my projects

In case you haven't seen my full size Lego R2-D2, check out L3-G0 @ http://L3-G0.com or http://youtube.com/myL3G0 - If you like my projects, please tweet or share, every bit helps, thanks! If you build one, please post a pix in the "I made one"

The original door intrudes into the interior too much, and the alternate door is better, but either doesn't have bilateral symmetry or I messed it up somehow. Also, those doors seem too skinny at the top and fat at the bottom.
I'm not sure how the originals were created, however I took the door, divided it in half (see the bilateral version), stuck the thing in a virtual model of the rest of the drop pod, and intersected it with the fins to make it fit fairly well. Please support my projects

In case you haven't seen my full size Lego R2-D2, check out L3-G0 @ http://L3-G0.com or http://youtube.com/myL3G0 - If you like my projects, please tweet or share, every bit helps, thanks! If you build one, please post a pix in the "I made one"

comments.text: Nice. Looks much better than my revamped doors.
comments.author: outofstep

comments.text: Thanks, thanks nice to hear, I really appreciated your doors though!  I may not have started the project without them.  You can see I used the same general shape though, but I stretched the walls and intersected them with an assembled model to try to fill in the gaps & stuff.  I also decided that I wanted some detail, but didn't want to really follow the GW pods because then people'd always compare them.
comments.author: outofstep

title: Leapfrog Creatr Dual Plastic roll holder

description.text: This roll holder is specific to the lp creatr dual and the rolls of material from MAXX.

I used green abs material, the following settings worked best for me: Extrusion multiplier: 0.95
top solid layers: 5
bottom solid layers: 3
skirt offset: 0 mm
skirt outlines: 4
Infill: concentric
Infill percentage: 15%
Infill angles: 45, -45
Bed temp: 70
Extruder temp: 195 ~took about 38 minutes to make

title: Hover balloon ( you need a rubber balloon )

description.text:
It's fun hover balloon.
You need a rubber balloon to run.
Print it and blow a balloon, put the balloon on it.
Then watch the balloon moving around ;D When you print it, please check bottom holes were made.
They are 2mm on file, but actually, were printed as less than 1mm.
That's suitable size, but some cases, the holes could be filled completely.

comments.text: I made one standard size and it won't fit my 12" balloons. It took about 29 mins and it printed from what I can tell properly but my balloon mouth piece was way to large. I am reprinting at 150% size and will let you know how it goes.
